Authors: Abdenour Zibani, Ali Shaukat, Hamida Benslimane
Title:
Corn Diseases in Algeria: First report of three Bipolaris and
two Exserohilum species causing leaf spots and leaf blight
Keywords:
molecular identification  pathogenicity  phylogeny 
phytopathogenic fungi
Abstract:
Corn is one of the most important crops in the world. In
Algeria, large areas of silage corn are mainly cultivated in the
southern part of the country, under center pivot irrigation system and
warm temperature conditions, which encourage leaf spot diseases
development. During 2016 and 2017, surveys for leaf diseases were
conducted across several corn fields in Algiers (north) and Ghardaïa
(south) regions, Algeria. Leaves samples exhibiting leaf spots were
collected for recovering the potential fungal pathogens associated with
the symptoms. Seventy isolates were recovered from the samples and
characterized using phylogenetic, morphological, and pathogenic
features. The isolates were grouped into two genera: Exserohilum and
Bipolaris. Based on ITS, GAPDH and RPB2 sequence data, Exserohilum
isolates were identified as E. rostratum and E. monoceras; while
Bipolaris isolates were identified as B. sorokiniana, B. microlaenae,
and B. omanensis. One isolate/species were tested for pathogenicity at
seedlings stage by inoculating them individually with spore suspension
on two susceptible corn cultivars “Giza 352” and “Qing Qing 300”. The
plants were rated for disease development 10 days-post inoculation. B.
sorokiniana produced light green to grayish leaf spots, rounded or
irregular (0.20.5 × 0.20.4 mm), or circular to oval distinct lesions,
white-gray with brown margins, surrounded by yellow-green halo (0.32.5 ×
0.31.3 mm). B. microlaenae induced grayish-white or light brown leaf
spots, encircled by a reddish border, 0.250.94 × 0.10.52 mm in size. B.
omanensis caused whitish irregular lesions or circular to oval necrotic
spots, whitish gray in color and surrounded by a dark brown border,
0.41.2 × 0.20.7 mm in size. E. rostratum induced grayish brown lesions
(0.25.0 × 0.21.5 mm), which may elongate and coalesce, forming tan to
dark brown necrotic streaks. Finally, E. monoceras induced grayish or
tan lesions (0.20.5 × 0.10.4 mm), surrounded by yellow to orange halo.
The lesions elongated parallel to the veins and may coalesce to form
long gray streaks corresponding to blighted tissue. To our knowledge,
this is the first report of these five fungal species associated with
corn leaf spots in Algeria. Furthermore, B. microlaenae and B. omanensis
are recorded for the first time in the world as causal agents of leaf
spot diseases in corn.
